Award.AwardTitle: IEEE PerCom 2018 Student Travel Support Request

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is for support of a travel IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) PerCom 2014 to be held in Athens, Greece, March 19 - 23, 2018. The purpose of this trip is to support approximately 15 - 20 students in the field of Pervasive Computing and Communications. PerCom 2018 will provide a leading edge scholarly forum for researchers, engineers, and students alike to share their state-of-the art research and developmental work in the broad areas of pervasive computing and communications.

This conference will provide the students with the opportunity to attend presentations of cutting-edge research results representing the state-of-the-art in pervasive computing, systems and applications. The attendees are offered a diversity of interactive forums, technical sessions, targeted workshops, interesting poster sessions, and exciting demonstrations. Students will have the opportunity to interact with the world's leading researchers in pervasive computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) is a flagship conference in the area of pervasive computing and networking dealing with internet of things, cyber-physical systems, and smart systems (e.g., smart city, smart energy, smart healthcare, etc.). The NSF travel funds helped support 7 U.S. based students to attend IEEE PerCom in 2018 conference held in Athens, Greece on March 19-23, 2018 (www.percom.org) and 11 students to attend IEEE PerCom 2018 held in Kyoto, Japan on March 11-15, 2019. Six of these students were women and two were under-represented minority students. They consisted of a mix of B.S., M.S. and Ph.D. students from smaller schools to big name schools.

 

Intellectual Merit: Papers presented at the IEEE PerCom 2018 and PerCom 2019 conferences were very high quality. The technical programs included a wide variety of topics in pervasive computing and networking as well as emerging topics like smartphone sensing, crowd sensing, smart city, security and social networks with applications to cyber-physical-human systems, smart and connected communities, smart healthcare, internet of things (IoT), security, energy and sustainability. The conference offered a valuable opportunity for the supported U.S. based students to attend keynote talks and technical sessions, learn about state-of-the-art research in pervasive computing, systems and applications through paper presentations and panel discussions, and participate in the Ph.D. forum, workshops, demo, poster, and work-in-progress sessions.  The students also got the opportunity to network with peers and top notch researchers in pervasive computing. They were highly motivated to pursue high quality research and eventually research careers upon graduation.

 

Broader Impacts. The NSF travel grant supported 18 students including women and under-represented minority students, to attend IEEE PerCom 2018 and PerCom 2019, a flagship conference in pervasive computing. The NSF travel grant opportunity was widely advertised that led to the selection of students competitively from an application pool of more than 40 students. Without NSF travel support, many of these students would not have otherwise attended this flagship conference
